Indians]] |30 |1997 |- | |[[Nomar Garciaparra]] |[[Boston Red Sox]] |30 |1997 |- | |[[Eric Davis (baseball)|Eric Davis]] |[[Baltimore Orioles]] |30 |1998 |- | |[[Luis Gonzalez (outfielder)|Luis Gonzalez]] |[[Arizona Diamondbacks]] |30 |1999 |- | |[[Albert Pujols]] |[[St. Louis Cardinals]] |30 |2003 |- | |[[Willy Taveras]] |[[Houston Astros]] |30 |2006 |- | |[[Moisés Alou]] |[[New York Mets]] |30 |2007 |- | |[[Ryan Zimmerman]] |[[Washington Nationals]] |30 |2009 |- | |[[Andre Ethier]] |[[Los Angeles Dodgers]] |30 |2011 |- | |[[Freddie Freeman]] |[[Atlanta Braves]] |30 |2016 |- |} Keeler's streak started in his final game of the 1896 season, and continued through the first 44 games of the 1897 season. Rollins ended the 2005 season with a 36-game streak and extended it through the first two games of the 2006 season. Sisler had a hit in the last game of 1924 and the first 34 games of 1925. Major League Baseball recognizes two hitting streak records: Longest hitting streak in one season, and longest hitting streak over multiple seasons (e.g. Rollins 2005–2006).{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/news/story?id=2178924|title=Phillies' Rollins extends streak to 36 games|author=|date=2 October 2005|website=ESPN.com}} Keeler's, Sisler's, and Rollins' streaks are listed as 44, 34, and 36 games when discussing ''single-season'' streaks, and 45, 35, and 38 games when discussing ''multiple-season'' streaks. This list omits [[Denny Lyons]] of the 1887 [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] [[Philadelphia Athletics (American Association)|Philadelphia Athletics]], who had a 52-game hitting streak.{{Cite web | title=Hitting Streaks, 30 Games or More | accessdate=August 7, 2011| url=http://www.thebaseballpage.com/stats/lists_feats/30game_hit_streaks.htm | archive-url=https://archive.is/20060409094305/http://www.thebaseballpage.com/stats/lists_feats/30game_hit_streaks.htm | dead-url=yes | archive-date=April 9, 2006 }} In [[1887 in baseball|1887]], the major leagues adopted a new rule which counted [[base on balls|walks]] as hits, a rule which was dropped after that season. Lyons hit in 52 consecutive games that season, but his streak included two games (#22 and #44) in which his only "hits" were walks. In [[1968 in baseball|1968]], MLB ruled that walks in 1887 would not be counted as hits, so Lyons' streak was no longer recognized, though it still appears on some lists. In 2000 Major League Baseball reversed its 1968 decision, ruling that the statistics which were recognized in each year's official records should stand, even in cases where they were later proven incorrect. Paradoxically, the ruling affects only hit ''totals'' for the year; the batting champion for the year is not recognized as the all-time leader despite having the highest single-season average under the ruling, and Lyons' hitting streak is not recognized. Ty Cobb, Sam Rice, and George Sisler are the only players with multiple streaks of 30 games or longer. There have been 129 single-season streaks of 25 games or more. The lowest [[batting average]] ever recorded during a hitting streak of 25 games or more was .304 by [[Bruce Campbell (baseball)|Bruce Campbell]] in [[1938 in baseball|1938]]. The highest was .486 during [[Chuck Klein]]'s streak in [[1930 in baseball|1930]]. Joe DiMaggio hit .408 during his record-holding 56 game streak.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/07/sports/baseball/for-the-braves-uggla-luck-is-not-a-statistic.html|title=For the Braves’ Uggla, Luck Is Not a Statistic|first=Rob|last=Neyer|date=6 August 2011|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}} In probability theory, every baseball game is a [[Bernoulli trial]] in which a hitter either does or does not get a hit. DiMaggio's streak of 56 consecutive games with hits awaits an equal streak: "The probability is .0003 that a .350 hitter will have a hitting streak of at least 56 games in a season. If there are about 4 such seasons per year in the future, we would expect to see such a streak, assuming the Bernoulli trials model, every 1/(.0003 x 4) = 833 years."C.M. Grinstead, W.P. Peterson & [[J. Laurie Snell]] (2011) ''Probability Tales'', page 37, [[American Mathematical Society]] {{ISBN|978-0-8218-5261-3}} ==Major League Baseball records by franchise== Only currently extant franchises are included on this list. Where a player had a significant streak while the team was in other than its current city, the records in these other cities are displayed. As above, for a multi-year streak, the single-season streak is shown in parentheses.http://baseballevolution.com/richard/hitting_streaks.xls Richard Van Zandt, BaseballEvolution.com, http://baseballevolution.com/richard/hitstreaks.html . Unrecognized by Minor League Baseball is the 69 game hitting streak by [[Joe Wilhoit]] in 1919. {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}}{{Use British English|date=July 2013}} {{Update-EB|date=January 2011}}
{{Infobox sport | name = Ice yachting | image = File:Adriaen Pietersz Der Winter.JPG|center|thumb| | alt = | imagesize = 350px | caption = [[Adriaen Pietersz van de Venne]], 1614 | union = | nickname = | first = | firstlabel = | region = United States, Canada, Netherlands and Finland | registered = | clubs = | contact = | team = | mgender = | type = | equipment = | venue = | glossary = | olympic = | world = | paralympic = | obsolete = }}
'''Ice yachting''' is the sport of sailing and racing [[iceboat]]s, also called [[ice]] [[yacht]]s.
== International popularity == Ice yachting is practiced in Austria, Germany, Great Britain, Poland, Norway and Sweden, to some extent, and is very popular in the Netherlands and on the [[Gulf of Finland]], but its highest development is in the United States and Canada. The Dutch ice yacht is a flat-bottomed boat resting crosswise upon a [[Plank (wood)|plank]]ing about three feet wide and sixteen long, to which are affixed four steel runners, one each at [[bow (ship)|bow]], [[stern]] and each end of the planking. The [[rudder]] is a fifth runner fixed to a tiller. Heavy [[mainsail]]s and [[jib]]s are generally used and the boat is built more for safety than for speed. The iceboat of the Gulf of Finland is a V-shaped frame with a heavy plank running from bow to stern, in which the [[Mast (sailing)|mast]] is stepped. The stern or steering runner is worked by a tiller or wheel. The [[sail]] is a large [[lug sail|lug]] and the [[Boom (sailing)|boom]] and [[Spar (sailing)|gaff]] are attached to the mast by travelers. The passengers sit upon planks or [[rope]] netting. The Russian boats were faster than the Dutch-built ice yachts.<ref name="EB1911">{{EB1911 |wstitle=Ice-Yachting |volume=14 |pages=241–242 |inline=1}}</ref> [[File:IJszeilen op de Gouwzee Weeknummer 38-52 - Open Beelden - 50860.ogv|thumb|right|Ice sailing in the Netherlands in 1938.]] [[File:Iceboaters1.jpg|300px|thumb| Ice sailing on [[Lake Balaton]], Hungary]]
== History ==
=== 18th century === Ice Yachting was born in Europe, but by 1790 the sport was in vogue on the [[Hudson River]], its headquarters being in [[Poughkeepsie (city), New York|Poughkeepsie, New York]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hvmag.com/core/pagetools.php?pageid=10755&url=/Hudson-Valley-Magazine/December-2013/A-History-of-Ice-Yachting-in-the-Hudson-Valley/&mode=print|title={{!}} A History of Ice Yachting in the Hudson Valley|website=www.hvmag.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> The boat was a square box on three runners, the two forward runners being nailed to the box and the third acting as a rudder operated by a tiller. This type of boat was first built in 1790 by Oliver Booth of Poughkeepsie. At this time, during the early days of the sport, it was an activity for the masses and not only for the wealthy.<ref name=":0" />
=== 19th century === The above primitive style was in general use until 1853, when triangular frames with boxes for the crew aft and jib and mainsail rig were introduced. Also at this time, the 1850s, ice yacht clubs were formed in [[Newburgh, New York|Newburgh]], [[New Hamburg, New York|New Hamburg]], Poughkeepsie, and [[Hyde Park, New York|Hyde Park]]. Members of the various clubs competed to win races such as the Ice yacht Challnge Pennant of America and the Captain William Drake Flag. They also raced against the newly introduced trains that began running along the Hudson River. <ref name=":0" />
A heavy, hard-riding type soon developed, with short gaffs, low sails, large jibs and booms extending far over the stern. It was over-[[canvas]]sed and the mast was stepped directly over the runner plank, bringing the centre of sail-balance so far aft that the boats were apt to run away, and the [[Over-canvassed sailing|over-canvass]]ing frequently caused the windward runner to swing up into the air to a dangerous height. The largest and fastest example of this type, which prevailed until 1879, was Commodore John. E. Roosevelt's first ''Icicle'', which measured {{convert|69|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} overall and carried {{convert|1070|sqft|m2|0|abbr=on}} of canvas. The ''Icicle'' once beat the Chicago Express on its run from Poughkeepsie to [[Ossining (village), New York|Ossining]].<ref name=":0" />
J.E. Roosevelt founded the Hudson River Ice Yacht Club in 1869. A 46-foot version of the ''Icicle'' recorded a speed of over 100 miles per hour.<ref name="Forbes:As The Hudson River Freezes, Classic Ice Yachts Emerge" />
In 1879, H. Relyea built the ''Robert Scott'', which had a single backbone and [[guy wire]]s, and it became the model for all Hudson River ice yachts. Masts were now stepped farther forward, jibs were shortened, booms were cut down, and the center of sail-balance was brought more inboard and higher up, causing the centers of effort and resistance to come more in harmony. The shallow steering-box became [[elliptical]].
The first race for the American Challenge Pennant occurred in 1881, which represents the championship of the Hudson River. The clubs that competed included the [[Hudson River]], North Shrewsbury, [[Orange Lake (New York)|Orange Lake]], [[Newburgh, New York|Newburgh]] and [[Carthage, New York|Carthage]] Ice Yacht Clubs. The races are usually sailed five times round a triangle of which each leg measures one mile, at least two of the legs being to windward.
=== 20th century === In 1911 modern ice yachts were made of a single-piece backbone the entire length of the boat, and a runner-plank upon which it rests at right angles, the two forming a [[kite (geometry)|kite]]-shaped frame. The best woods for these pieces are [[basswood]], [[butternut (tree)|butternut]], and [[pine]]. They are cut from the log in such a way that the heart of the timber expands, giving the planks a permanent curve, which, in the finished boat, is turned upward. The two forward runners, usually made of soft [[cast iron]] and about {{convert|2.7|ft|m|0|abbr=on}}. long and {{convert|24|in|cm|0}} high, are set into oak frames a little over 5 feet long and 5 inches high. The runners have a cutting edge of 90%, though a V-shaped edge is often preferred for racing. The rudder is a runner about {{convert|3.7|ft|m|0|abbr=on}}. long, worked by a tiller, sometimes made very long, 7½ feet not being uncommon. This enables the [[helmsman]] to lie in the box at full length and steer with his feet, leaving his hands free to tend the sheet. Masts and spars are generally made hollow for racing-yachts and the rigging is pliable steel wire. The sails are of 10-ounce duck for a boat carrying {{convert|400|sqft|m2|-1|abbr=on}} of canvas. They have very high peaks, short hoists and long booms. The mainsail and jib rig is general, but a double-masted lateen rig has been found advantageous. The foremost ice-yacht builder of America was G. E. Buckhout of Poughkeepsie.<ref name="EB1911" />
[[File:icesailing.jpg|300px|right|thumb| Ice sailing on Lake Balaton]]
An ice yacht is about {{convert|40|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} in length and can carry six or seven passengers or crew, who are distributed in such a manner as to preserve the balance of the boat. In a good breeze the crew lie out on the windward side of the runner-plank to balance the boat, and reduce the [[pressure]] on the leeward runner. A course of {{convert|20|mi|km|0}} with many turns has been sailed on the Hudson in less than 48 minutes, the record for a measured mile with flying start being at the rate of about {{convert|72|mi|km|0}} an hour. In a high wind, however, ice yachts often move at the rate of 85 and even {{convert|90|mi|km|0}} an hour.<ref name=EB1911/>
On the [[headlands and bays|bays]] near New York, a peculiar kind of iceboat has developed, called scooter, which may be described as a toboggan with a sail. A typical scooter is about {{convert|15|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} long with an extreme beam of {{convert|5|ft|m|0|abbr=on}}, perfectly oval in form and flat. It has mainsail and jib carried on a mast 9 or 10 feet long and set well aft, and is provided with two long parallel metal runners. There is no rudder, the scooter being steered entirely by trimming the sails, particularly the jib. As the craft is flat and [[buoyant]], it sails well in water, and can thus be used on very thin ice without danger. A speed of {{convert|50|km/h|abbr=on}} has been attained by a scooter.<ref name=EB1911/>
== Classes of ice yachts == In the early 20th century ice yachts were divided into four classes, carrying respectively {{convert|600|sqft|m2|-1|abbr=on}} of canvas or more, between 450 and 600, between 300 and 450, and less than {{convert|300|sqft|m2|-1|abbr=on}}. In the 1930s the Detroit News held a competition to design an inexpensive iceboat for ordinary (not wealthy) citizens. A new type of boat, known at the DN, resulted.<ref name="Forbes:As The Hudson River Freezes, Classic Ice Yachts Emerge">{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Daniel|title=As The Hudson River Freezes, Classic Ice Yachts Emerge|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/danielfisher/2014/03/07/as-the-hudson-river-freezes-over-classic-ice-yachts-emerge/#604ec0391212|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=21 February 2018|date=7 March 2014}}</ref> The prevalent yachts used today are known as "stern-steerers" because of the skate in the back which is used to steer them. They have a long central beam, often hollow, clamped to large runner planks close to the mast that carry the forward skates. The sailors ride in an oval pod at the stern, which often has elegant varnished rails and turned stiles. One sailor steers and the other works the sheets, or control lines for the sails. <ref name="Forbes:As The Hudson River Freezes, Classic Ice Yachts Emerge" />
== North American ice yachting == Ice yachting is very popular on the [[Great Lakes]], both in the United States and Canada, the [[Kingston, Ontario]] Club having a fleet of over 25 sail. Other important centers of the sport are the Lake Geneva, Wisconsin area, with an average of twenty-five sailing days a season for the last five years, Lakes [[Lake Minnetonka|Minnetonka]] and [[White Bear Lake, Minnesota|White Bear]] in [[Minnesota]], Lakes [[Lake Winnebago|Winnebago]] and [[Lake Pepin|Pepin]] in [[Wisconsin]], Bar Harbor Lake in [[Maine]], the [[St. Lawrence River]], Quinte Bay and [[Lake Champlain]].<ref name="EB1911" />
==See also== *[[Land sailing]] *[[Ice boat]] *[[International DN]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Ice}}

In [[chess]], '''International Arbiter''' is a title awarded by [[FIDE]] to individuals deemed capable of acting as arbiter in important chess matches. The arbiters are responsible for ensuring the rules and laws of chess are adhered to. The title was established in 1951.
Requirements for the title to be awarded are detailed in section B.06 of the FIDE Handbook. As well as thorough knowledge of the [[rules of chess|laws of chess]] and a proved impartiality, they include the ability to speak a FIDE-approved language and previous experience as an arbiter in important tournaments. The [[FIDE]] World Chess Federation displays the list of International Arbiters with their ID numbers, name, and title on its official web site.
Some individuals have had careers as strong players and later become International Arbiters. Notable examples include: * [[Albéric O'Kelly de Galway]], [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] who was third [[correspondence chess]] world champion before becoming an International Arbiter in 1962 and acting as Chief Arbiter at the [[World Chess Championship 1966|1966]] and [[World Chess Championship 1969|1969]] [[over-the-board]] [[World Chess Championship|World Championship]] matches; * [[Lothar Schmid]], Grandmaster who finished joint second with the then [[World chess champion|World Champion]] [[Tigran Petrosian]] at Bamberg 1968 and was also a strong correspondence player before becoming an International Arbiter in 1975 and acting as Chief Arbiter in the [[World Chess Championship 1972|1972]], [[World Chess Championship 1978|1978]], and [[World Chess Championship 1986|1986 World Championship]] matches. * [[Gideon Ståhlberg]], Grandmaster who was [[Sweden]]'s top player for many years and refereed several of [[Mikhail Botvinnik]]'s world championship matches. * [[Zoltán Ribli]], was a [[World Chess Championship|World Championship]] [[Candidates Tournament|Candidate]] twice and [[Hungarian Chess Championship|Hungarian Champion]] three times. * [[Yuri Averbakh]], was a [[World Chess Championship|World Championship]] [[Candidates Tournament|Candidate]] and winner of the 1954 [[USSR Chess Championship]]. * [[Salo Flohr]] * [[Nana Alexandria]] * [[Peter Romanovsky]] * [[Isaac Kashdan]] * [[Daniel Yanofsky]] * [[Robert Wade (chess player)|Robert Wade]] * [[Vasja Pirc]] * [[Nonna Karakashyan]]
==External links== *[http://www.fide.com/component/handbook/?id=41&view=category Requirements for the title of International Arbiter]
{{chess-tournament-stub}} [[Category:Chess arbiters|*International Arbiter]] [[Category:Chess titles]] [[Category:1951 in chess]] [[Category:Awards established in 1951]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} '''James Love''' (1721–1774) was the [[pseudonym]] of British poet, playwright and actor '''James Dance'''. He is best known for his poem ''Cricket: An Heroic Poem'' (1744).
==Life and work== Son of [[George Dance the Elder]], who worked as an architect and city surveyor, Love was himself a cricketer, being a member of [[Richmond Cricket Club (18th century)|Richmond Cricket Club]]. Richmond was a leading club in the 1740s and Love may have represented [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] too. However, no details have survived of his playing career.<ref name=ASW35>{{cite book |last=Ashley-Cooper |first=F. S. |authorlink=F. S. Ashley-Cooper |title=At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742–1751 |publisher=''Cricket'' magazine |date=20 March 1900 |page=35}}</ref>
He was also likely the founder of the Theatre Royal in [[London Borough of Richmond upon Thames|Richmond upon Thames]], which he managed from 1766 to 1773. In 1763, at [[Drury Lane]] in London, he played the role of [[Falstaff]], for which he became best known as an actor, his authorial pseudonym serving also as his stage name. In 1766 he played his signature role in a new play, [[William Kenrick (writer)|William Kenrick]]'s ''[[Falstaff's Wedding]]'', intended as a sequel to ''[[Henry IV, Part 2]]''. He performed, too, in both [[Dublin]] and [[Edinburgh]], of which he was a sometime manager. Invited to [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], in 1762, he retained a connection to it for the rest of his life.
As a writer, Love met success with such Rome-inspired Pantomimes as ''The Witches; or, Harlequin Cherokee'' ([[1762 in literature|1762]]), ''The Rites of Hecate; or, Harlequin from the Moon'' ([[1763 in literature|1763]]) and ''The Hermit; or, Harlequin at Rhodes'' ([[1766 in literature|1766]]), in addition to ''Cricket''. His earliest work was ''Pamela'' ([[1742 in literature|1742]]).
{{wikisource|Cricket: An Heroic Poem}} He is famous within sporting circles for his ''Cricket: An Heroic Poem'' (1744), whose line "The strokes re-echo o'er the spacious ground" has been quoted in the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]''. Its subtitle reads thus: "Illustrated with the Critical Observations of Scriblerus Maximus. To which is Added an Epilogue, call'd 'Bucks Have at Ye All'. Spoken by Mr. King, at the Theatre Royal in Dublin, in the Character of Ranger, in the Suspicious Husband."
On 4 July 1745, the ''Daily Advertiser'' advertised it at 1/-. A footnote to the publication adds that it was "[p]rinted for W Bickerton at the Gazette in the Temple Exchange near the Inner Temple Gate, Fleet Street."
==Family== Love was also the brother of [[George Dance the Younger]], who took on the same occupation as his father. It is probable that both the Younger and the Elder helped to construct the Richmond Theatre. According to Dorothy Stroud, "references to the building are vague and two of them, while agreeing as to sponsors, differ as to the name of the designer. A third gives it to [David] [[David Garrick|Garrick]] and it is evident that there was a good deal of confusion as to the various participants."<ref>Quoted in ''Performances at Richmond's Theatre Royale: 15th June 1765'' 2008.</ref>
==See also== *[[Cricket poetry]]

''London Borough of Richmond upon Thames''. 10 October 2008. <ref>http://www.richmond.gov.uk/home/leisure_and_culture/local_history_and_heritage/local_studies_collection/local_history_notes/performances_at_richmonds_theatre_royale/richmonds_theatre_royale_june_1765.htm?ts=larger%27</ref> (accessed 22 October 2008).

{{infobox country at games | NPC = MLT | NPCname = Malta Federation of Sports Associations for Disabled Persons | games = Summer Paralympics | year = 2008 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = [[Beijing]] | competitors = 1 | sports = 1 | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Malta]]''' competed at the '''[[2008 Summer Paralympics]]''' in [[Beijing]], [[China]]. This was the first time in twenty-four years that Malta competed in the games; the last time was at the [[1984 Summer Paralympics]]. The country's delegation consisted of a single competitor, 18-year-old sprinter Antonio Flores. He was a member of [[Pembroke Athleta]] and trained under the club's coach, Jivko Jetchev. Flores left for Beijing on September 1.{{cite web |title=Maltese aspirations at the Paralympics |publisher=DI-VE |date=2008-08-27 |url=http://www.di-ve.com/Default.aspx?ID=65&PID=11&NewsID=53891&Action=1&newscategory=23 |accessdate=2008-08-27 }} ==Results== Flores entered only one event - the 100m sprint in the T44 category. He finished 5th out of 6 in his heat, and did not advance to the final.[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=MLT&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Malta at the Paralympics], [[International Paralympic Committee]] {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Name !Sport !Event !Time !Rank |- | [[Antonio Flores (athlete)|Antonio Flores]] || [[Athletics at the 2000 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Men's 100m T44 || 12.71 || 5th in heat 2;
did not advance |} ==See also== *[[Malta at the 2008 Summer Olympics]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{NPCin2008SummerParalympics}} [[Category:Nations at the 2008 Summer Paralympics]] [[Category:Malta at the Paralympics|2008]] [[Category:2008 in Maltese sport|Paralympics]] {{Malta-sport-stub}} {{2008-Paralympics-stub}}

'''Marathon mountain bike races''', often referred to as '''[[cross-country cycling|cross-country]] marathon''' ('''XCM'''), are a very demanding form of [[mountain bike racing]] covering at least {{convert|40|km|mi|abbr=off}} usually in mountainous terrain. Events held in Europe are typically just a little longer than the average cross country mountain bike race. Marathon events in the USA and Canada are typically longer than {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=off}} and are very different from cross country races.
==UCI events==
The [[Union Cycliste Internationale|UCI]] has established a championship series for such events, the Marathon World Cup. The 2014 UCI rules limit events to distances between {{convert|60|km|mi|abbr=on}} and {{convert|160|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Almost all of the participants are elite professional mountain bike racers. There is an annual [[world championship]] event, the [[UCI Mountain Bike Marathon World Championships]]. The races can be run over as a single or multi-lap course, however, the course cannot cover the same lap more than three times.
[[File:JMajors900.png|thumb|right|A racer in the Wilderness 101]]
==Non-UCI events== Non-UCI events routinely cover much longer distances. The typical event in the USA is either based on time, typically 12 or 24 hours, or distance, the most common being {{convert|100|mi|km}}. Events based on hours typically allow either people to compete individually or as part of the team. Distance events are almost all solo events. The number of these events and those taking part in them have grown greatly. The first such events began to be held routinely in the early 1990s typically had less than 50 racers. In 2006 nearly 100 events were held and most had more than 150 racers.
The world's largest mountain bike marathon race by the number of participants is the [[Birkebeinerrittet]], {{convert|95|km|mi}}, held annually in Norway. While the distance is short for a marathon mountain bike event, the number of participants and history make it noteworthy.
== Marathon MTB Events on Wikipedia == * [[Montezuma's Revenge (bicycle race)|Montezuma’s Revenge]] * [[Wilderness 101 Mountain Bicycle Race]] * [[Mohican MTB 100]] * [[Lumberjack 100]] * [[The Endurance 100]] * [[Breckenridge 100]] * [[Leadville Trail 100 MTB]] * [[Brazil Ride]] more than 500 km over 7 days * [[Chupacabras (cycling race)]] * [[Birkebeinerrittet]] * [[Shenandoah 100|Shenandoah Mountain 100]] * [[FAT 55 Oakridge Mountain Bike Marathon]], 55 miles * [[La Ruta de los Conquistadores]], 161 miles, 3 stages * [[Yak Attack]]
== References == <references />

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Peaks Ice Arena | image = Peaks Ice Arena (35720941122).jpg | caption = Looking east at the Peaks Ice Arena, June 2017 | location = 100 North
Seven Peaks Boulevard
[[Provo, Utah]],
[[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|14|5|N|111|38|17|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = September 17, 1997 | built = 1997–1998 | opened = {{Start date|1998|11|20}} | renovated = | expanded = | owner = Provo City/Utah County Ice Sheet Authority{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldextra.com/news/local/central/provo/title-to-ice-arena-transferred-to-ice-sheet-authority/article_bba4e08d-dbb3-513e-8629-ced3e96f5c67.html|title=Title to ice arena transferred to Ice Sheet Authority|last=Pugmire|first=Genelle|newspaper=[[Daily Herald (Utah)|Daily Herald]]|publisher=[[Ogden Newspapers]]|location=Provo, Utah|date=3 Nov 2012|accessdate=3 Nov 2012}} | cost = $12.4 million [[United States dollar|USD]] | architect = Valentiner, Crane, Brunjes, Onyon (VCBO) Architecture | general_contractor = Hogan and Associates | capacity = 2,300 | tenants = BYU Men's Ice Hockey (1999- present)
Peaks Youth Hockey Association (2000- present )
[[2002 Winter Olympics|XIX Olympic Winter Games]] (February 2002) | website = {{URL|http://peaksarena.provo.org}} }} '''Peaks Ice Arena''' is an indoor [[ice hockey and figure skating]] [[arena]] in [[Provo, Utah|Provo]], [[Utah]], [[United States]], located {{convert|43|mi|km}} south of [[Salt Lake City]]. It was built, along with the [[Maverik Center]] (originally known as the E Center) in [[West Valley City, Utah|West Valley City]], to serve as an ice hockey and figure skating practice venue for the [[2002 Winter Olympics]]. It currently serves as the home of the [[BYU Cougars men's ice hockey]] team, Peaks Youth Hockey Association, several high school teams, the Peaks Figure Skating Club, as well as a Learn-to-Skate USA program for beginning skaters of all ages. ==History== Provo was chosen as the site for an Olympic venue because the leaders of [[Utah County, Utah|Utah County]] refused to support Utah's 1989 Olympic referendum unless they were promised at least one Olympic event would be held in the county. Originally county leaders wanted a speed skating oval built somewhere in Provo or on the campus of [[Utah Valley University]]; others suggested the game's Closing Ceremony could be held at [[Brigham Young University]]'s [[LaVell Edwards Stadium|football stadium]].{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/52993/UTAH-COUNTY-WONT-BACK-GAMES-UNLESS-IT-CAN-HOST-AN-EVENT.html|title=Utah County won't back games unless it can host and event|last=Morris|first=Michael|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=28 Jun 1989|accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} After the 1989 Olympic referendum passed, and Salt Lake City lost its 1991 bid to host the [[1998 Winter Olympics]], the Utah Sports Authority and Provo City decided to wait until Salt Lake City bid again for the 2002 Winter Olympics before any venue planning would start. After Salt Lake City won the 2002 Olympic bid in 1995, planning began again for what venue Utah County could host. It was decided that the city of Provo would host the venue, but that it would only be a practice ice sheet, mostly like to be built in the planned [[Provo Towne Centre]] mall.{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/423329/CITIES-GREET-THE-NEWS-WITH-JUBILATION-WARNING.html|title=Cities greet the news with jubilation, warning|last1=Romboy|first1=Dennis|last2=Edwards|first2=Alan|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=17 Jun 1995|accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} Eventually plans changed and a larger, yet still only a practice ice facility, was planned to be constructed near Provo's East Bay Golf Course. Utah County, Provo, and [[Salt Lake Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games of 2002|SLOC]] all okayed the plans and committed to building the $7.7 million (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|7.7|1996|r=2}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}}) facility.{{cite news |title=Utah County to Receive Ice Sheet|author=|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|location=Salt Lake City|page=D2|date=22 Mar 1996}} But in July 1996, before construction had started, the owners of Provo's Seven Peaks Waterpark approached the city and asked that the arena be built on the park's property, and Seven Peaks would pay for an additional ice sheet to be constructed in the same building.{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/502324/PROVO-TASK-FORCE-AND-7-PEAKS-HAVE-OLYMPIC-DREAMS.html |title=Provo Task Force and 7 Peaks have Olympic dreams|last=Rayburn|first=Jim|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=18 Jul 1996 |accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} The plan was approved by county officials October 14, 1996, with Provo paying $2 million, Utah County $2 million, SLOC $3 million, and Seven Peaks donating land for the arena and parking spaces.{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/519283/SEVEN-PEAKS-RESORT-SKATES-AWAY-WITH-7-MILLION-OLYMPIC-ICE-ARENA.html|title=Seven Peaks Resort skates away with $7 million Olympic Ice Arena |last=Rayburn|first=Jim|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=15 Oct 1996|accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} Valentiner, Crane, Brunjes, Onyon Architecture was chosen to design the arena. [[File:Peaks Ice Arena (35890064815).jpg|thumb|left|The additional ice sheet at the Peaks Ice Arena, June 2017]] On September 17, 1997 ground was broken for construction next to Seven Peaks Waterpark. It was to be {{convert|84000|sqft|m2|sigfig=2}} in size, with two ice sheets side by side. One ice sheet would have seating for about 2,000 spectators while the other would seat 300. By the time ground was broken the price had increased to $8.5 million, $1.5 million more than originally planned; the extra cost would be paid for by Seven Peaks.{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/583542/Big-stink-finally-leads-to-Provo-ice-rinks.html|title=`Big stink' finally leads to Provo ice rinks|last=Romboy|first=Dennis|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=17 Sep 1997|accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} Soon after construction had begun SLOC decided to host competitive hockey events in the new arena, versus the original plan to use the arena for practices, and using Utah Valley University's [[UCCU Center]] (then known as the McKay Events Center) for the competitions. SLOC would contribute $5.25 million (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|5.25|1997|r=3}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}}) towards the project, the cost of which had just jumped to $10.75 million, with the addition of 12 locker rooms instead of four, extra seating, and other minor additions to the original plan.{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/591673/Expansion-of-Peaks-rinks-OKd-for-Games.html|title=Expansion of Peaks rinks OK'd for Games|last=Romboy|first=Dennis|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=29 Oct 1997|accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} The arena opened November 20, 1998 in what was considered a "soft opening", and following the completion of minor work, the arena was supposed to have a grand opening in January or February 1999. But in December 1998 allegations of a scandal involving SLOC members, and members of the [[International Olympic Committee]] concerning the [[2002 Winter Olympic bid scandal|2002 Olympic bid]] surfaced, pushing back the grand opening.{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/673860/Ice-Sheet-Authority-putting-grand-opening-plans-on-ice-Seven-Peaks-gala-postponed-due-to-SLOC.html|title=Ice Sheet Authority putting grand opening plans on ice|last=Haddock|first=Sharon|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=12 Jan 1999|accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} As a result, the grand opening celebration was held September 29, 1999, and the venue hosted its first event, a hockey game between the [[University of Minnesota]] Duluth Bulldogs and the [[University of Calgary]] Oval Extremes, two days later. The completed arena cost $12.4 million to build, included two ice sheets, had seating for over 2,000 spectators, and was {{convert|110000|sqft|m2|sigfig=2}} in size.{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/720240/Arena-skates-toward-debut-Provo-facilitys-grand-opening-runs-through-weekend-BR.html|title=Arena skates toward debut Provo facility's grand opening runs through weekend|last=Curreri|first=Frank|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=29 Sep 1999 |accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} On November 20, 2008 Provo City took control of the arena from Seven Peaks owner Max Rabner, resolving a lawsuit that had been on going for years over the original construction and management agreements. The arena is now operated by the Parks and Recreation Department of Provo.{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705264766/Provo-takes-helm-of-Peaks-Ice-Arena.html|title=Provo takes helm of Peaks Ice Arena|last=Dana|first=Jens|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=21 Nov 1998|accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} ==2002 Winter Olympics== [[File:Olympic hockey game peaks arena.jpg|thumb|right|February 2002 Olympic ice hockey game between Austria and Lavia inside the arena]] During the 2002 games both men's and women's [[Ice hockey at the 2002 Winter Olympics|ice hockey games]] and practices were held in the arena. Because of its original size over 6,000 temporary seats had to be installed to boost the ice center's capacity to 8,400, including press members. 93 percent of tickets were sold, for a total 131,067 of spectators witnessing events in the arena.{{cite book|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2002/2002v1.pdf|title=Official Report of the XIX Olympic Winter Games|author=[[Salt Lake Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games of 2002|Salt Lake Organizing Committee]]|year=2002|isbn=0-9717961-0-6|page=91|format=PDF|accessdate=7 Dec 2010}} ==The arena today== The arena is home to the Peaks Figure Skating Club. The arena also serves as home ice for the [[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA]] collegiate hockey team of [[Brigham Young University]], and high school teams including Timpanogos, Utah County Independent, Lehi, Payson, Spanish Fork and Springville, as well as the Peaks Youth Hockey Association. The arena is open to the public for ice skating, skating lessons, and can even be used for indoor soccer games. ==References== {{reflist|22em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Peaks Ice Arena}} * {{official|http://peaksarena.provo.org}} * [http://www.byuhockey.org/ Brigham Young University Hockey] {{2002 Winter Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues in ice hockey}} {{Provo, Utah}} [[Category:Venues of the 2002 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic ice hockey venues]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Utah]] [[Category:Sports venues in Utah]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Utah County, Utah]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:Brigham Young University]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Provo, Utah]] [[Category:1998 establishments in Utah]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Provo, Utah]]

{{Infobox baseball team | Name = Petach Tikva Pioneers
פתח תקווה פיונירס | Logo = [[Image:Petach Tikva Pioneers.jpg]] | Founded = {{baseball year|2006}} | Location = {{Flagicon|ISR}} [[Petah Tikva]] | Stadium = [[Yarkon Sports Complex]] | League = [[Israel Baseball League]] | LeagueChamps = 0 | Colors = Red and Black | Season = | Record = | Series = | SeriesChamps = | Manager = | h_cap =dc143c | h_body =dc143c | h_rightarm =dc143c | h_leftarm =dc143c | h_pattern_ra = _blackborder_trim | h_pattern_la = _blackborder_trim | h_pants = ffffff | h_socks =dc143c | a_pattern_b =_unknown }} The '''Petach Tikva Pioneers''' ({{lang-he|'''פתח תקווה פיונירס'''}}) was an [[Israel]]i [[baseball]] team from [[Petah Tikva]] in the [[Israel Baseball League]]. They finished the inaugural 2007 regular season in last place (9-32; .220), and lost to the [[Modi'in Miracle]] in the quarterfinals of the 2007 championship. ==History== [[Image:Petach Tikva Pioneers shirt logo.jpg|thumb|left]] The name for the Pioneers was chosen in recognition that [[Petah Tikva]] was founded in 1878 by religious pioneers from [[Jerusalem]], who were led by [[Yehoshua Stampfer]], Yoel Moshe Salomon, Zerach Brant, and David Gutmann, as well as [[Lithuania]]n Rabbi [[Aryeh Leib Frumkin]]. The first player selected by the Pioneers in the inaugural draft was [[Dominican Republic|Dominican]] outfielder Reynaldo Cruz,{{cite web |url=http://www.israelbaseballleague.com/news/pressreleases/index.html?article_id=24 |title=First Player Draft in IBL History Yields Bumper Crop |accessdate=2007-04-29 |publisher=IsraelBaseballLeague.com }} who later suffered a [[concussion]] and did not play for the rest of the season. [[Ken Holtzman]] managed the Pioneers in the 2007 inaugural season of the Israel Baseball League, up until the last week of the season. Holtzman in his major league career was the only pitcher since the 1880s to throw 2 no-hitters for the Cubs, and his 174 career victories are the most in the major leagues by a [[Jewish]] pitcher. He also held the record for most pitching appearances by a Jewish pitcher until 1998. ==Stadium== Located at the [[Yarkon Sports Complex]] in [[Petach Tikva]]. ==2007 roster== {{Petach Tikva Pioneers roster}} ==Footnotes== ==External links== *[http://www.israelbaseballleague.com/teams/petach/ Official site of the Petach Tikva Pioneers] {{Israel Baseball League}} {{Baseball in Israel}} [[Category:Baseball teams in Israel]] [[Category:Sport in Petah Tikva]] {{israel-sport-stub}} {{Asia-baseball-team-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} '''[[Rugby union]] in [[Laos]]''' is a minor but growing sport.
==Governing body== The governing body is the Lao Rugby Federation, which was founded in 2001.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irb.com/unions/union=11000114/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928052844/http://www.irb.com/unions/union%3D11000114/index.html |archivedate=28 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>http://www.laorugby.com/Lao_Rugby_Federation/Home.html</ref>
==History== Rugby was originally introduced when Laos was part of [[French Indochina]], but this was mainly by French expatriates. After independence there was a long hiatus, as financial and political forces, from famine to the [[Vietnam War]] meant it was impossible for the game to be played.
The Indochinese Cup was established in 1999, as a four sided tourname between Vietnamese teams from [[Saïgon]] and [[Hanoi]], [[Vientiane]] ([[Laos]]) and [[Phnom Penh]] in Cambodia.<ref name=CFRhist>http://www.cambodiarugby.org/content.php?secid=10&catid=16&id=12 Cambodian Federation of Rugby, history, accessed 28 June 2009</ref>
Laos takes part in the South East Asia region of the [[Asian Five Nations]]
==See also== * [[Laos national rugby union team]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110928052844/http://www.irb.com/unions/union%3D11000114/index.html IRB Laos page] * [http://www.laorugby.com official union page] * [http://www.rugbyinasia.com/laos/index.php Rugby in Asia, Laos page] * [http://www.arfu.com/index.php Asian Rugby Football Union] *{{fr}} [http://www.lestimbresdurugby.com/Archivesdurugby/Pays/Laos.htm Archives du Rugby: Laos]

{{Sociology}} '''Sociology of sport''', alternately referred to as '''sports sociology''', is a sub-discipline of [[sociology]] which focuses on [[sport]]s as social phenomena. It is an area of study concerned with various socio-cultural structures, patterns, and [[organization]]s or groups involved with sport.
There are many perspectives through which [[sport]] can be viewed. Therefore, very often some binary divisions are stressed, such as: professional vs. amateur, mass vs. top-level, active vs. passive/spectator, men vs. women, sports vs. play (as an antithesis to organized and [[Institutionalisation|institutionalized]] activity). Following [[feminist]] or other reflexive and tradition-breaking [[paradigms]] sports are sometimes studied as contested activities, i.e. as activities in the centre of various people/groups interests (connection of [[sports]] and [[gender]], [[mass media]], or state-politics).
In most premodern societies, the gender role for females and males in sports was reinforced at a young age. The sociology that formed surrounding sports enforced the idea that sports were too masculine for women and are encouraged to play noncompetitive games while men were able to compete.<ref>Rowe, David C, and William N. Thompson. “Sociology of sports.” Encyclopædia Britannica, Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., 10 Mar. 2017, www.britannica.com/topic/sports/Sociology-of-sports.</ref> The impact of sports and games was to prepare young children for adulthood. The separation between the roles of men and women in a society of sports is expressed through media and gender identity. On media, the sports viewership varies by gender. Men's sports are more prominent in the media versus women's sports and the sports broadcast vary. On NCAA news, the text and text space greater than 2:1 coverage of men’s sports over women’s, the pictures are around 2:1 male athletes over female athletes.<ref>Shifflett, Bethany, and Rhonda Revelle. “Gender Equity In Sports Media Coverage: A Review Of The Ncaa News.” Journal of Sport and Social Issues, vol. 18, no. 2, 1994, pp. 144–150., doi:10.1177/019372394018002004.</ref> For males the sports typically include football, hockey, baseball, soccer, basketball, pro wrestling and boxing,<ref>Messner, Michael A., et al. “The Televised Sports Manhood Formula.” Journal of Sport and Social Issues, vol. 24, no. 4, 2000, pp. 380–394., doi:10.1177/0193723500244006.</ref> while women's sports covers figure skating, gymnastics, skiing, and diving.<ref>Sargent, Stephanie L, et al. “The Gender Gap in the enjoyment of televised sports.” Sage Journals, Feb. 1998.</ref> There is a contrast in the sports for each gender: the men's sports include confrontative, combative coordination and the women's sports are less aggressive and more individual and stylish. Participation in “masculine” sports creates gender identity conflict for females, likewise participation in “feminine” sports creates gender identity conflict for males.
The emergence of the sociology of sport (though not the name itself) dates from the end of the 19th century, when first [[social psychology|social psychological]] experiments dealing with group effects of competition and pace-making took place. Besides [[cultural anthropology]] and its interest in games in the human culture, one of the first efforts to think about sports in a more general way was [[Johan Huizinga]]'s ''Homo Ludens'' or [[Thorstein Veblen]]'s ''Theory of the Leisure Class''.<ref>Lueschen, G. 1980. Sociology of Sport: Development, Present State, and Prospects. ''Annual Review of Sociology'', 6: 315 — 347.</ref> In 1970, sports sociology gained significant attention as an organized, legitimate field of study. The North American Society for the Sociology of Sport was formed in 1978 with the objective of studying the field.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.nasss.org/about/about-nasss/| title=About NASSS| publisher=North American Society for the Sociology of Sport| accessdate=February 5, 2017}}</ref> Its research outlet, the ''Sociology of Sport Journal'', was formed in 1984.
Today, most sports sociologists identify with at least one of four essential theories that define the relationship between sports and society, namely [[structural functionalism]], [[Conflict theories|conflict theory]], [[critical theory]], and [[symbolic interactionism]].
==Alternative viewpoints== [[Jean-Marie Brohm]] in "Sport: A Prison of Measured Time"<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Sport_a_prison_of_measured_time.html?id=vYEwAQAAIAAJ| title=Sport, a prison of measured time: essays| author=Jean Marie Brohm| publisher=Ink Links Ltd. |date=1978| ISBN=0906133017}}</ref> presents a [[Marxism|Marxist]] critique of organized sport as an instrument of indoctrination and subordination.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2189107.Sport| title= Sport: A Prison Of Measured Time: Essays by Jean-Marie Brohm | publisher=Goodreads | accessdate=February 4, 2017}}</ref>

Stade Victor Boucquey | tenants = [[Olympique Lillois]] (1907–1944)
[[Lille OSC]] (1944–1974) | seating_capacity = 15,000 | dimensions = }} '''Stade Henri-Jooris''' was a sports [[stadium]] in [[Lille]], [[France]]. The stadium, used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches was able to hold 15,000 people and was home stadium of [[Olympique Lillois]] and [[Lille OSC]]. Originally it was known as ''Stade de l'avenue de Dunkerque''; from 1907 to 1943, the stadium's name was the ''Stade Victor Boucquey''. That year it was renamed after the former president of Olympique Lillois Henri-Jooris (who died four years before). During the [[1938 World Cup]], it hosted one game. ==1938 FIFA World Cup== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:70%;" |- !Date !Time !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |12 June 1938||17:00||{{fb|SUI}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–2||{{fb|HUN|1940}}||[[1938 FIFA World Cup#Quarter-finals|Quarter-finals]]||style="text-align:center;"|15,000 |} {{1938 FIFA World Cup stadiums}} {{Lille OSC}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Henri Jooris}} [[Category:Lille OSC|Stade Henri-Jooris]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in France]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1902]] [[Category:Buildings and structures demolished in 1975|Stade Henri-Jooris]] [[Category:Football venues in France]] [[Category:1938 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lille|Stade Henri-Jooris]] [[Category:Sports venues in Nord (French department)]] {{France-sports-venue-stub}}

[[File:Walter Frederick Morrison.jpg|thumb|Walter Fredrick Morrison promoting his Pluto Platters, the forerunner of the Frisbee, in the 1950s.]] '''Walter Frederick "Fred" Morrison''' (January 16, 1920 in [[Richfield, Utah]] – February 9, 2010 in [[Monroe, Utah]])<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700008690/Frisbee-inventor-Fred-Morrison-dies.html|title=Frisbee creator Fred Morrison dies|last=Arave|first=Lynn|date=10 February 2010|work=[[Deseret News]]|accessdate=11 February 2010}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] inventor and entrepreneur, best known as the inventor of the [[Frisbee]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Frisbee inventor dies at 90 | publisher=[[Washington Post]] | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/02/11/AR2010021104625.html | accessdate=2010-02-14 | date=2010-02-11 | last=Alden | first=Doug}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Fred Morrison, Creator of a Popular Flying Plate, Dies at 90 | publisher=[[New York Times]] | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/13/us/13morrison.html?scp=1&sq=Walter%20Frederick%20Morrison&st=cse | accessdate=2010-02-14 | date=2010-02-13 | last=Fox | first=Margalit}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Walter Fredrick Morrison dies at 90; father of the Frisbee | publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-fred-morrison13-2010feb13,0,7076853.story | accessdate=2010-02-14 | date=2010-02-13 | last=McLellan | first=Dennis}}</ref>
Morrison claimed that the original idea for a flying disc toy came to him in 1937, while throwing a popcorn can lid with his girlfriend, Lu, whom he later married. The popcorn can lid soon dented which led to the discovery that cake pans flew better and were more common. Morrison and Lu developed a little business selling "Flyin' Cake Pans" on the beaches of [[Santa Monica, California]].
During [[World War II]] he learned something of aerodynamics flying his [[P-47 Thunderbolt]] in Italy. He was shot down and was a [[prisoner of war]] for 48 days.
In 1946, he sketched out a design (called the Whirlo-Way) for the world's first flying disc. In 1948 an investor, Warren Franscioni, paid for molding the design in plastic. They named it the Flyin-Saucer. After disappointing sales, Fred & Warren parted ways in early 1950. In 1954, Fred bought more of the Saucers from the original molders to sell at local fairs, but soon found he could produce his own disc more cheaply. In 1955, he and Lu designed the Pluto Platter, the archetype of all modern flying discs. On January 23, 1957, they sold the rights for the Pluto Platter to the [[Wham-O]] toy company. Initially Wham-O continued to market the toy solely as the "Pluto Platter", but by June 1957 they also began using the name ''Frisbee'' after learning that college students in the Northeast were calling the Pluto Platter by that name. Morrison also invented several other products for Wham-O, but none were as successful as the Pluto Platter.
Morrison and his wife, Lu Nay Morrison had three children. Lu died in 1987.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/technology-obituaries/7223147/Fred-Morrison.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Fred Morrison | date=2010-02-12 | accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref>
There is a [[disc golf]] course in [[Holladay, Utah]] named in his honor.
Morrison died in his home at the age of 90 on February 9, 2010.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/US/02/12/frisbee.morrison.obit/index.html?hpt=T2 | work=CNN | title=Frisbee inventor dies at 90 – CNN.com | accessdate=2010-05-27 | date=2010-02-12}}</ref>
